content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given the structure of this game, it appears to be a repeated version of the Prisoner's Dilemma, where cooperation between players is not necessarily optimal due to the individual incentive for self-gain. However, over the course of 75 rounds, the player has an opportunity to establish a strategy that maximizes their overall earnings.

In this scenario, it seems that choosing R consistently would lead to higher earnings in the long run, as picking R will result in a higher payout (45$) when the opponent chooses B, while earning 40$ if both players choose B. The downside is that choosing R when the opponent chooses R results in no earnings, but since this outcome only happens half of the time, it may not significantly impact the overall earnings over 75 rounds.

On the other hand, choosing B consistently would lead to lower but more stable earnings, as both players earn 40$ if they choose B simultaneously. The downside is that when the opponent chooses R, the player will only earn 35$. However, since there are more opportunities for both players to choose B (75 rounds - 37 rounds where both players pick R or B) than picking R (37 rounds), a consistent B strategy might lead to slightly higher earnings.

However, it's worth considering that the opponent in this game could be adopting a similar rational analysis and may switch strategies based on their observations of the player's choices. In such a case, it would be more advantageous to mix strategies (i.e., choose R some rounds and B other rounds) to make it difficult for the opponent to predict one's actions and maximize earnings over the long run.

With that said, I will choose a mixed strategy by picking both R and B throughout the game and append my choice as follows: {R} or {B}, depending on the round number.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 35$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 35$. Please play the next round.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 35$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, I initially chose a cooperative strategy by choosing B, but my opponent chose R instead, resulting in a lower payout (35$) for me and no earnings for my opponent. Given that my opponent seems to be adopting a competitive strategy, I will now switch back to a mixed strategy by choosing R for the next round: {R}

By alternating between cooperative (B) and competitive (R) choices, I hope to confuse my opponent's prediction of my future actions and potentially increase my overall earnings over the long run. It's important to keep in mind that the opponent may also be adapting their strategy based on observations, so it's essential to remain flexible and adjust my approach as needed throughout the game.
